trans-unit.source: Binary wheels and source code are available from the Python package index. Thank you to Isuru Fernando for working on infrastructure to build those wheels.

trans-unit.source: Then look at the docs there, and you’re in business. No idea what function name to look for? Just use the same grep procedure to look for keywords.
trans-unit.target: Then look at the docs there, and you’re in business. No idea what function name to look for? Just use the same grep procedure to look for keywords.

trans-unit.source: This tells you how to call the function from Python. You can then use grep to fish out the right Fortran source:
trans-unit.target: 这告诉你如何从 Python 中调用函数。然后你可以使用grep来找出正确的Fortran源代码。

trans-unit.source: This wrapper is far from comprehensive. It just catches the things I ended up needing. Nonetheless, the FMMs and a fair bit of other useful stuff is accessible.
trans-unit.target: 这个包装盒远远不够全面。它只是抓住了我最终需要的东西。尽管如此,FMMs和其他一些有用的东西都可以访问。

trans-unit.target: 像往常一样掰着手指头算账。

trans-unit.source: pyfmmlib is a Python wrapper for fmmlib2d and fmmlib3d implementations of the fast multipole method for Laplace and Helmholtz potentials by Zydrunas Gimbutas and Leslie Greengard (and including code by many more people).
trans-unit.target: pyfmmlib is a Python wrapper for fmmlib2d and fmmlib3d implementations of the fast multipole method for Laplace and Helmholtz potentials by Zydrunas Gimbutas and Leslie Greengard (and including code by many more people).

trans-unit.source: suffix. This means they apply to whole vectors of arguments at once. They’re also parallel via OpenMP.
trans-unit.target: suffix. This means they apply to whole vectors of arguments at once. They’re also parallel via OpenMP.
